JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
BALTIMORE, MD., MAY

VOL. XVII, NO. 27.

Poem for the Class of '13

'VARSITY DOWNS NAVY NINE
Crack Midshipmen Team Defeated in
Eleventh Inning—Pieper Works
in Old Style.

In a hard-fought, up-on-yourtoes, eleven-inning game, the Black
and Blue nine split athletic honors
between us and the Navy by winning from the midshipmen with a
score of i to o.
In all except the track meet, our
athletic contests with the sailor
boys have been as closely contested
as games could well be. After the
6 to 3 score in football, and the
4 to 4 score in lacrosse, the Black
and Blue felt they owed the Navy
a beating. It was hard work, but
they gave it.
Between Pieper and Vinson on
the mound, the game was a fight
from start to finish. It would 1)0
hard to say where the laurels kAA.
Besides pitching steadily, "Smoke"
had the situation in control at all
stages of the game, only giving
one pass, while the sailor lad allowed two.
Williams' shoe-string catch in the
first saved two runs. Porter played
a truly exceptional game. Webster was pretty busy, making some
long running catches. "Hub" Rice
threw out Vinson trying to steal
second, and caught the same player
again off first base.'
In the tenth, with two men on
the sacks, when it looked like the
Navy was sure to score, Webster
caught a line-drive, saving the
Black and Blue.
But it was in the eleventh inning
that joy came to the J. H. U. With
two men out, the 'Varsity got a
runner home that made them the
victors. The run was well earned.
Hobbs singled to right and stole
second; Schultz followed with a
fast grounder to center, and Hobbs
reachel home.

12, 1913.

"Thus have I made my own opinions clear,
Yet neither praise expect' nor censure fear;
And this unpolished rugged verse I chose
As fittest for discourse, and nearest prose;
For while from sacred truth I do not swerve,
Tom Shadwell's or Tom Sternhold's rhymes will serve."
-DRYDEN.

Of Harvard's elms let others sing the praise,
Rich with the memories of by-gone days;
Let others sing Old Nassau's princely style,
And "quad" set round with many a Gothic pile;
Those leafy lanes where study walks alone,
Those fields which lusty sport claims for its own,
That fair seclusion and that peace divine,
Be theme for other muses, not for mine.
Be mine to sing a dingy city street,
Where every trade and all conditions meet;
Where twice each day pour forth the hosts of toil,
Those bent on plunder and those meant for spoil,
And all is uproar, hurry, dust and strife,
As power and weakness grapple for the life.
Here, HOPKINS, hast thou will'd to make thy stand—
Could Learning choose a nobler in the land?
For, say, shall Learning sit upon a hill,
And those alone with sweet refreshment fill,
Who have the leisure and the strength to climb
To her coy oracle and shrine sublime?
Not so! Her place is ill the crowded street,
Her richest field, her most productive seat;
Here only, in the nation's pulsing heart
She acts her noblest and her truest part—
Sends her benignant strength through every vein,
And has through each that strcngth renewed again;
For what is Learning if she may not pour
Upon the Present all the Past's large store;
And what is Learning if she may not read
The Present's lesson against future need,
And list those mighty voices which go up
Each day from mill and-mart, from street and shop?
True Learning is no rustic denizen,
Her home is in the busy haunts of men.
And there, 0 HOPKINS, hast thou fed her flame
For thirty seasons, and enhanced her name;
To thy broad bosom hast thou yearly press'd
The offspring of the nation's worst and best,
And sent them forth to all the walks of life
To act their part more nobly in the strife;
Till in, the course of slow revolving time
We came, who bring thee now this bit of rhyme;
And thou didst teach us mid the city's roar
To con the living book of nature o'er,
And in the lesson of each science see
The noble meaning of Democracy.
The time draws nigh when thou, too, shalt retreat
To rural shades, to Homewood's sylvan seat;
Oh, may thou there preserve within thy ken
The common hopes and fears of common men!
Yet grateful are we, Alma Mater 'dear,
That thou hast press'd us to thy bosom here,
While still about thy knees there ebbs andlfiows
The surging tide of human weal and woes.
J. S. D., '13.

COLLEGIATE
CHAMPIONS
Lacrosse Team Astonishes Supporters
By Remarkable Score.

By defeating Swarthmore by the
score of 7 to 4, the 'Varsity lacrosse squad surpassed the expectations of its most ardent supporters on Saturday. Another championship banner has been added to
our Trophy Room collection.
With two experienced veterans
out of the game, "Buts" Sutton
and "Tommy" Troxell, the Black
and Blue rooters were a little dubious as to what the outcome would
be. But while the Indians were
being worsted by the track team
at Homewood, and "Smoke" Pieper
and his teammates were defeating
the crack Navy nine, the Black and
Blue twelve gave the wood to the
Garnet.
The 'Varsity starting off with its
usual rush scored two goals in
quick succession; Knipp and Beatty
turned the trick.
This proved unfortunate, for
things looked too easy and the team
slackened up, with the result that
Swarthmore quickly tied the score
and then drew one point in the lead.
But even then the Black and Blue
did not steady down, although
Beatty again evened up by netting
a long shot. Before the half was
over, however, the Garnet made a
fourth tally, again taking the lead.
The second half showed a remarkable improvement on the part
of Hopkins. The defense tightened
up, the mid-field followed the ball
harder, the attack was here, there,
and everywhere, shooting hard
from all angles.
Then things roughened up. Two
Hopkins men were seen and penalized, one Swarthmore player being similarly treated. In spite of
this, and though the whole Hopkins attack was on the defensive,
the Black and Blue scored twice
more before the final whistle blew,
leaving us victors and champions.

THE MADISON

Many Positions Offered 1913 Medical
School Class—Tempting Offer
From North Carolina.

Many letters have been received
by Dr. Winford H. Smith, superintendent of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and Dr. J. Whitridge
Williams, dean of the Medical
School, from hospital superintendents, the g,ovrnment hospital
service, and public boards of health,
asking or graduates of the Johns
Hopkins Medical School. All of the seventy men who will
graduate in June have received
flattering offers from hospitals. In
fact, more requests for graduates
have come in than can be filled.
Although some of these offers are
very inviting, the students always
consult Dr. Smith or one of the
other professors before accepting
them.
Perhaps the.most tempting offer
to Hopkins men has been made by
the North Carolina State Board of
Health. Dr. W. S. Rankin, secretary of the Board, has offered five
positions as county health physicians, with salaries of from two
thousand to three thousand dollars
a year. These offers are being
considered by a number of Hopkins men who are from the South.

12, 1913.

MEETING OF GROTIUS SOCIETY
The Society Holds Its Final Meeting.
Elects Officers—Plans for Future.
Has Had Good Year.

The. final meeting of the Grotius
Society, for the scholastic year
1912-13, was held last Tuesday,
May 6, in the Donovan Room.
Officers elected for the first part
of next year were: Weber, president; Richmond, vice-president ;
Schaffer, secretary; Gminder, treasurer, and Hammond, curator...
There had been scheduled ;I
lecture by a member of the Society opposed to woman suffrage,
but it was postponed until the University reopens next October. Plans
were discussed for next year's
work, and it was decided . to •continue along the same line, to have
literary programs every week, and
special public lectures at intervals
throughout the year. There is a
committee at work on a play that
the Society hopes to give soon after
the recommencing of school. Taken
all in all, the Society had a very
successful year, and hopes for continued success in the future.
T. Poole Maynard, A. II. '05.

Women's Civic League Mass-meeting.%

Last Monday night McCoy Hall
was the scene of a mass-meeting
under the auspices of the Women's
Civic League and the endorsement
of the Inter-Church Federation o f
Baltimore. The meeting was arranged for by the 1 ilk Committee
of. the Women s League, but mill<
not the only topic considered
at the meeting. Eugenics and infant mortality, two other subjects
of study in the country-wide campaig:i for better babies, were also
discussed. Eugenics was the field
Of Dr. 1 renry
Goddard, of Vineland, N. J. Dr. Goddard is not
only an authority upon this subject, but he is also a psychologist
of note and the author of works
on feeble-mindedness and social
problems. .The speaker on infant
mortality was Dr. J. H. Mason
Knox, Jr., the only Baltimorean on
the list of speakers, superintendent
of the Thomas Wilson Sanatorium
and head physician of the Babies'
Al ilk Fund Association of the
Maryland Association for the Prevention of Infant Mortality. Dr.
Charles E. North spoke on "Pure
Milk Supply for a. Large City."

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 12, 1913.
The Grotius Society.

a man of literary attainments, but
also an advocate of international
arbitration. In this way the name
of the Society shows just what
sort of model it has assumed.
This brief summary of the history of the Grotius Society will
serve, to shpw that it is no upstart
club, of no importance, and destined to fade into oblivion as fast
as it was compounded. It has a
worthy, if not ostentatious, history
behind it, and deserves that every
one at least give it due recognition.
The Society is not restricted in
its membership. Any one who attends the meetings and can counterfeit a dollar bill can become a member. The meetings are held every
Tuesday at one o'clock in the Donovan Room. If you get hungry
you can eat your lunch there, provided you leave no crumbs to draw
flies! Don't think that the Society
is either above your capacity or below your dignity. The object of
the Society, as stated in its constitution, is "to discuss any subject
or subjects that may be of interest
to its members." Anything that
interests you will interest some one
else. All the classes are invited.
Freshmen will there find an opportunity to make use of whatever
parliamentary knowledge they have
learned in their high school literary
associations. Sophomores can learn
there how to become good secretaries or treasurers, and so prepare
for a responsible position with a
big trust company !. Juniors can
there find an outlet for their exuberant spirits, and the seniors also
delight in displaying there their
wonderfully collected and carefully
assimilated stock of learning. So•
when the call is made next October,
let there be a generous response.
Of course every one will not be interested, but those who like to talk,
discuss, debate, listen, practice parliamentary "stunts," indulge their
histrionic propensities, or pay dues,
all such are urged to become members of the Grotius Society. THE
NEWS-LETTER feels confident that
no one will at all regret having
taken this step.

Although the Grotius Society has
existed under that name ever since
last Christmas, yet we have discovered that there are some men
around the University who either
have not heard of the Society or
its name, or who do not know what
it is and what it is for. It is because of this fact that we are giving this space to tell the ignorant
ones just what the Grotius Society
is. We do not believe this is a
waste of space, for we are heartily
in support of the Society, agree
with its aims and endeavors, and
are, therefore, glad of the opportunity to help it along.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 12, 1913.
SENIOR PROM THURSDAY, JUNE 5

SAMPLE SALESCRECK

To Be One of Most Attractive Events of
Year—Fisher's Orchestra Tennis
Costumes to Be Worn.

Isaac Hamburger & Sons

The Senior Prom Committee has
decided that the date for the 1913
dance shall be Thursday, June 5.
It has also decided that this dance
shall be the best held in McCoy
Hall for some years, and it will
have to ''go some" to beat the cotillons of the season just past. The
Senior Prom Committee is divided
into smaller committees. Each of
these smaller ones is doing its best
.to outdo the others in thinking up
good things for the senior dance.
The supper, the punch, the music,
.the decorations, the souvenirs, all
.are going to be the best ever.
McCoy Hall always looks extremely gay. on the night .of, the
-senior prom. On June 5 • streamers of the class colors vill stretch
from the middle of the ceiling to
all corners. Class banners of various colors will hang over the
corridors. Palms will stretch across
the platform, and, behind these,
Fisher's Orchestra will, in ragtime
style, play "Down in New Orleans"
and "Here Comes My Daddy
Now." The girls will be the prettiest of Baltimore. And the fellows,
with their flannel trousers and blue
coats, will give to the hall a delightfully summer appearance. The
fellow who misses this senior prom
will miss• one of the most attractive
events of the year.
• Freshman Tennis Team.

The freshman tennis team is now
a reality. A large squad of Men
have been practicing ever since the
Homewood field opened this, season,
and though some have -dropped,
the squad still numbers . between
twelve ,and fifteen men. .Since an
elimination tournament • was impracticable, it has become an exceedingly difficult matter to pick
the men to play on the team.
. The schedule is by no means a
light owe and provides for five and
possibly six matches. On May 2
the team met. the City College contingent, losing, unfortunately, all
the matches in singles ; but winning, however, in the doubles. On
Friday, May 9, they met the Polytechnic team. On the 14th .the
;team will try conclusions with Marstons on the i6th, Gilman's Country School, and on the 23rd, the
sophomore class team. The schedule calls for a great deal of hard
work, but the team is expected to
come through with a majority of
wins.
The match with the sophomores
has been placed last on the schedule, naturally enough, and it will
be as keenly disputed and as hard
fought, as any of the freshmansophomore events.
The team: Hardy, Hayes, McDowell, Thomas, Rowland, Evitt,
and Web Peploe, manager.

Dr. Charles F. Painter Honored.

In the appointment of Dr. Charles
Nr. Painter, of the Class of 1891,
as dean of one of the largest medical schools in the country—the
medical school of Tuft's College, at
edford, Mass.—another honor has
come to a graduate of our University.

Dr. Painter has been for the last
seven years a professor of surgery
at the school of which he now becomes dean. He is a member of a
numebr of medical societies in this
country and the editor-in-chief of
the American Association of Orthopedic Surgery.

The following official announcement has been posted on the bulletin boards of the University and
Medical School:
Annual Johns Hopkins Tennis
Tournament, 1913.
"The 'Varsity Tennis Tournament
for 1913 will commence Wednesday, Max' 14, and will continue
thereafter daily until' completed.
Play will begin each afternoon at
4.30, though matches may be played
b.\ agreement at any hour. The
events will be singles, doubles and
consolation singles. All contestants
defeated in the first round actually
played will be eligible for the consolations. Prizes will be awarded
to the winner and runner-up in
singles; the winner in the consolations, and the winners of the
doubles. Any regularly registered
member of any department of the
University is eligible to enter the
tournament.
"All seven courts at Homewood
will be used, and Wright and Ditson championship balls will be furnished for each match.
"The entrance fee will be fifty
cents for the singles, and fifty cents
for each member of a team in
doubles, for those men who hold
five-dollar gymnasium lockers; for
all others the fee will be one dollar
for the singles and one dollar for
the doubles. Send entries to one
of the following:
"H. E. Corner, '14, Box 102; A.
L. Hammond,'14, Box 252; Julian
Marshall,'is; William Merrick,'15,
and Hiram Woodward, '16."
The Tournament has been set for
an earlier date than usual this year,
so as to leave plenty of time before
examinations. In addition, the late
hour for starting in the afternoon
will allow those to play who would
not wish to cut "lab."
The success of the Tournament
in previous years and the tennis
boom during this spring seems to
assure a large number of entries.
Although as many as forty-eight
entries were received last year, the
1913 committee had already a good
part of that number even on Saturday. One good indication is the
number of men from the lower
classes who will compete. The ,
winners of the singles tournaments
of the last three years were: 1910,
Perce; 1911, Post; 1912, DuBray.
"Johnny" Huck was runner-up in
1911, Julian Sears in 1912. The
three last mentioned men are still
at the University.
Next Saturday morning the 'Varsity tennis team will play Lehigh
University at Homewood. The
visiting team will be entertained in
Baltimore Thursday night. Lehigh conies here with a formidable
reputation in tennis. They have
already met such teams as Wesleyan, Lafayette, and Haverford.
Lehigh is captained by a Baltimorean, Ferdinand Turnbull,

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 12, 1913.
BOAT RIDE ON FRIDAY, JUNE 6
Seniors Plan Prom,Boat Ride, Gala Day,
and Classday for Senior Week,
June 5 to 10, Inclusive.

At a meeting of the senior class,
held last Friday, the final report of
the. Senior Week Committee was
unanimously adopted. The report
in condensed 'form, and the several
subcommittees are as follows:
J. E. Richardson, Jr., chairman
ex-officio of all the committees.
Thursday at 8.30 P. M., Senior
Prom; Donoho, chairman; Schmied,
Ray, Uhler, Brady.
Friday at 3 P. M., boat ride;
Sears, Sattler, Jacobs.
Saturday at 3 P. M., Homewood
Gala Day; at 8 P. M., supper at
Thompson's; Meekins, Breuninger.
Monday at 3 P. M., Class Day,
Rusk; Class Play, written by Wolman, Rusk and Hildebrandt; Class
Valedictory, by J. S. Dickinson;
address by Honorary Class President. At 8 P. M., Reception given
by Dean Griffin to seniors at the
Hopkins Club.
Tuesday at 3 P. M., Commencement; at 8 P. M., Faculty reception.
Invitations in charge of G. E. W.
Hardy, Jr.
Senior prom tickets can be secured from Donoho for $2.50. The
seniors who have paid their class

dues and the senior week assessment will be given the boat ride
free. The underclasses will be addressed by Chairman Richardson
during the coming week, when the
price of tickets will be announced
and other arrangements for the
boat ride will be made.
How to Tell a- Turkey's Age.

"Casey," said Pat, "how do yez
tell th' age of a tu-u-rkey ?"
"Oi can always tell by the teeth,"
said Casey.
"By the teeth !" exclaimed Pat.
"But a tu-u-rkey has no teeth."
"No," admitted Casey, "but Oi
have."

Election to Phi Beta Kappa.

May 12, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LIMER :
DP:AR SIR—The advisability of an
intellectual aristocracy is seldom
questioned. Perhaps this is true because a criticism of so well established an institution as the Phi Beta
happa might seem to be prompted
by those whom we call "sore-heads"
and "sour grapes." There is,.however, wisdom in the objections which
might be advocated against the
method of recruiting this notable
fraternity. That no other method
.of election has been adjudged practicable seems to alter the case but
slightly.
The absurdity of over-classification attributed t9 Matthew Arnold,
who insisted on grading mathematically the victims of his literary
criticism, can be applied to these
Phi Beta Kappa elections. Psychologists, it is true, may feel that
there is a relation between the power of the intellect and the actual
weight of the brain. Nevertheless,
it is to be hoped that our wits will
refrain from proposing the chemical balance as a Phi Beta Kappa
qualification. It seems almcst as
ridiculous, furthermore, to consider
the tens which the "bluffers- and the
"bootlickers" pull as indices to the
highest order of mental development. True, this year's selection is
entirely irrelevant to this discussion—Mr. Dickinson, Mr. 1\ fartin,
Mr. Sears,.Mr. \\Tolman, Mr. Nodeserving
vak and Mr. Gruse
of the highest honors.
Even Professor Ames with all
his mathematical dexterity would
fail, should .he try the impossible.
"Brain ?—you can't give a number to
it !" In the graduate department
those who received their keys have
been tested by a far better standard.
The strength of intellect is not
tossed about in the shape .of nines
and tens, through meaningless additions and divisions. The inadequacy of.Phi Beta Kappa qualifications cannot, nevertheless, be
championed as an excuse for doing
poor work. Because Woodrow
Wilson happened to stand fortieth
in his class is no reason for one
flunking "Pyhsics and Psychology...

DEBATING COUNCIL

The Western High School of
Washington captured the third annual interscholastic meet which was
held in conjunction with the Carlisle meet and promoted by the
University Athletic Association.
Western High School had 28
points; Mercersburg, 26; Episcopal
High School, 21 ; Tome, Jo; Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, 9; Baltimore City College, 6; Gilman's
Country School, 5.
Some hundred and odd schoolboys took part in the contests, making it the greatest scholastic meet
held recently in these parts. The
inclement weather was detrimental
to good performances; nevertheless,
the work of several individuals was
creditable. Kinsolving-, of Episcopal, won first in the high hurdles,
second in the low, first in the high
jump and second in the broad
jump. Jones, of Western High
School, won three events, the wo
and 220 yard dashes, and the broad
jump.
Polytechnic won the mile relay
race from City College with ease.
The race was won in the first lap
after a considerable distance had
been gained by Jacobs, the B. P. I.
runner. Jacobs had previously won
the 220 low hurdles.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
BALTIMORE, MD., MAY

VOL. XVII, NO. 27.

Poem for the Class of '13

'VARSITY DOWNS NAVY NINE
Crack Midshipmen Team Defeated in
Eleventh Inning—Pieper Works
in Old Style.

In a hard-fought, up-on-yourtoes, eleven-inning game, the Black
and Blue nine split athletic honors
between us and the Navy by winning from the midshipmen with a
score of i to o.
In all except the track meet, our
athletic contests with the sailor
boys have been as closely contested
as games could well be. After the
6 to 3 score in football, and the
4 to 4 score in lacrosse, the Black
and Blue felt they owed the Navy
a beating. It was hard work, but
they gave it.
Between Pieper and Vinson on
the mound, the game was a fight
from start to finish. It would 1)0
hard to say where the laurels kAA.
Besides pitching steadily, "Smoke"
had the situation in control at all
stages of the game, only giving
one pass, while the sailor lad allowed two.
Williams' shoe-string catch in the
first saved two runs. Porter played
a truly exceptional game. Webster was pretty busy, making some
long running catches. "Hub" Rice
threw out Vinson trying to steal
second, and caught the same player
again off first base.'
In the tenth, with two men on
the sacks, when it looked like the
Navy was sure to score, Webster
caught a line-drive, saving the
Black and Blue.
But it was in the eleventh inning
that joy came to the J. H. U. With
two men out, the 'Varsity got a
runner home that made them the
victors. The run was well earned.
Hobbs singled to right and stole
second; Schultz followed with a
fast grounder to center, and Hobbs
reachel home.

"Thus have I made my own opinions clear,
Yet neither praise expect' nor censure fear;
And this unpolished rugged verse I chose
As fittest for discourse, and nearest prose;
For while from sacred truth I do not swerve,
Tom Shadwell's or Tom Sternhold's rhymes will serve."
-DRYDEN.

Of Harvard's elms let others sing the praise,
Rich with the memories of by-gone days;
Let others sing Old Nassau's princely style,
And "quad" set round with many a Gothic pile;
Those leafy lanes where study walks alone,
Those fields which lusty sport claims for its own,
That fair seclusion and that peace divine,
Be theme for other muses, not for mine.
Be mine to sing a dingy city street,
Where every trade and all conditions meet;
Where twice each day pour forth the hosts of toil,
Those bent on plunder and those meant for spoil,
And all is uproar, hurry, dust and strife,
As power and weakness grapple for the life.
Here, HOPKINS, hast thou will'd to make thy stand—
Could Learning choose a nobler in the land?
For, say, shall Learning sit upon a hill,
And those alone with sweet refreshment fill,
Who have the leisure and the strength to climb
To her coy oracle and shrine sublime?
Not so! Her place is ill the crowded street,
Her richest field, her most productive seat;
Here only, in the nation's pulsing heart
She acts her noblest and her truest part—
Sends her benignant strength through every vein,
And has through each that strcngth renewed again;
For what is Learning if she may not pour
Upon the Present all the Past's large store;
And what is Learning if she may not read
The Present's lesson against future need,
And list those mighty voices which go up
Each day from mill and-mart, from street and shop?
True Learning is no rustic denizen,
Her home is in the busy haunts of men.
And there, 0 HOPKINS, hast thou fed her flame
For thirty seasons, and enhanced her name;
To thy broad bosom hast thou yearly press'd
The offspring of the nation's worst and best,
And sent them forth to all the walks of life
To act their part more nobly in the strife;
Till in, the course of slow revolving time
We came, who bring thee now this bit of rhyme;
And thou didst teach us mid the city's roar
To con the living book of nature o'er,
And in the lesson of each science see
The noble meaning of Democracy.
The time draws nigh when thou, too, shalt retreat
To rural shades, to Homewood's sylvan seat;
Oh, may thou there preserve within thy ken
The common hopes and fears of common men!
Yet grateful are we, Alma Mater 'dear,
That thou hast press'd us to thy bosom here,
While still about thy knees there ebbs andlfiows
The surging tide of human weal and woes.
J. S. D., '13.

COLLEGIATE
CHAMPIONS
Lacrosse Team Astonishes Supporters
By Remarkable Score.

By defeating Swarthmore by the
score of 7 to 4, the 'Varsity lacrosse squad surpassed the expectations of its most ardent supporters on Saturday. Another championship banner has been added to
our Trophy Room collection.
With two experienced veterans
out of the game, "Buts" Sutton
and "Tommy" Troxell, the Black
and Blue rooters were a little dubious as to what the outcome would
be. But while the Indians were
being worsted by the track team
at Homewood, and "Smoke" Pieper
and his teammates were defeating
the crack Navy nine, the Black and
Blue twelve gave the wood to the
Garnet.
The 'Varsity starting off with its
usual rush scored two goals in
quick succession; Knipp and Beatty
turned the trick.
This proved unfortunate, for
things looked too easy and the team
slackened up, with the result that
Swarthmore quickly tied the score
and then drew one point in the lead.
But even then the Black and Blue
did not steady down, although
Beatty again evened up by netting
a long shot. Before the half was
over, however, the Garnet made a
fourth tally, again taking the lead.
The second half showed a remarkable improvement on the part
of Hopkins. The defense tightened
up, the mid-field followed the ball
harder, the attack was here, there,
and everywhere, shooting hard
from all angles.
Then things roughened up. Two
Hopkins men were seen and penalized, one Swarthmore player being similarly treated. In spite of
this, and though the whole Hopkins attack was on the defensive,
the Black and Blue scored twice
more before the final whistle blew,
leaving us victors and champions.

THE MADISON

Many Positions Offered 1913 Medical
School Class—Tempting Offer
From North Carolina.

Many letters have been received
by Dr. Winford H. Smith, superintendent of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, and Dr. J. Whitridge
Williams, dean of the Medical
School, from hospital superintendents, the g,ovrnment hospital
service, and public boards of health,
asking or graduates of the Johns
Hopkins Medical School. All of the seventy men who will
graduate in June have received
flattering offers from hospitals. In
fact, more requests for graduates
have come in than can be filled.
Although some of these offers are
very inviting, the students always
consult Dr. Smith or one of the
other professors before accepting
them.
Perhaps the.most tempting offer
to Hopkins men has been made by
the North Carolina State Board of
Health. Dr. W. S. Rankin, secretary of the Board, has offered five
positions as county health physicians, with salaries of from two
thousand to three thousand dollars
a year. These offers are being
considered by a number of Hopkins men who are from the South.

12, 1913.

MEETING OF GROTIUS SOCIETY
The Society Holds Its Final Meeting.
Elects Officers—Plans for Future.
Has Had Good Year.

The. final meeting of the Grotius
Society, for the scholastic year
1912-13, was held last Tuesday,
May 6, in the Donovan Room.
Officers elected for the first part
of next year were: Weber, president; Richmond, vice-president ;
Schaffer, secretary; Gminder, treasurer, and Hammond, curator...
There had been scheduled ;I
lecture by a member of the Society opposed to woman suffrage,
but it was postponed until the University reopens next October. Plans
were discussed for next year's
work, and it was decided . to •continue along the same line, to have
literary programs every week, and
special public lectures at intervals
throughout the year. There is a
committee at work on a play that
the Society hopes to give soon after
the recommencing of school. Taken
all in all, the Society had a very
successful year, and hopes for continued success in the future.
T. Poole Maynard, A. II. '05.
a mining and consulting geologist, located in Chattanooga, Tenn.

Last Monday night McCoy Hall
was the scene of a mass-meeting
under the auspices of the Women's
Civic League and the endorsement
of the Inter-Church Federation o f
Baltimore. The meeting was arranged for by the 1 ilk Committee
of. the Women s League, but mill<
not the only topic considered
at the meeting. Eugenics and infant mortality, two other subjects
of study in the country-wide campaig:i for better babies, were also
discussed. Eugenics was the field
Of Dr. 1 renry
Goddard, of Vineland, N. J. Dr. Goddard is not
only an authority upon this subject, but he is also a psychologist
of note and the author of works
on feeble-mindedness and social
problems. .The speaker on infant
mortality was Dr. J. H. Mason
Knox, Jr., the only Baltimorean on
the list of speakers, superintendent
of the Thomas Wilson Sanatorium
and head physician of the Babies'
Al ilk Fund Association of the
Maryland Association for the Prevention of Infant Mortality. Dr.
Charles E. North spoke on "Pure
Milk Supply for a. Large City."

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 12, 1913.
The Grotius Society.

a man of literary attainments, but
also an advocate of international
arbitration. In this way the name
of the Society shows just what
sort of model it has assumed.
This brief summary of the history of the Grotius Society will
serve, to shpw that it is no upstart
club, of no importance, and destined to fade into oblivion as fast
as it was compounded. It has a
worthy, if not ostentatious, history
behind it, and deserves that every
one at least give it due recognition.
The Society is not restricted in
its membership. Any one who attends the meetings and can counterfeit a dollar bill can become a member. The meetings are held every
Tuesday at one o'clock in the Donovan Room. If you get hungry
you can eat your lunch there, provided you leave no crumbs to draw
flies! Don't think that the Society
is either above your capacity or below your dignity. The object of
the Society, as stated in its constitution, is "to discuss any subject
or subjects that may be of interest
to its members." Anything that
interests you will interest some one
else. All the classes are invited.
Freshmen will there find an opportunity to make use of whatever
parliamentary knowledge they have
learned in their high school literary
associations. Sophomores can learn
there how to become good secretaries or treasurers, and so prepare
for a responsible position with a
big trust company !. Juniors can
there find an outlet for their exuberant spirits, and the seniors also
delight in displaying there their
wonderfully collected and carefully
assimilated stock of learning. So•
when the call is made next October,
let there be a generous response.
Of course every one will not be interested, but those who like to talk,
discuss, debate, listen, practice parliamentary "stunts," indulge their
histrionic propensities, or pay dues,
all such are urged to become members of the Grotius Society. THE
NEWS-LETTER feels confident that
no one will at all regret having
taken this step.

Although the Grotius Society has
existed under that name ever since
last Christmas, yet we have discovered that there are some men
around the University who either
have not heard of the Society or
its name, or who do not know what
it is and what it is for. It is because of this fact that we are giving this space to tell the ignorant
ones just what the Grotius Society
is. We do not believe this is a
waste of space, for we are heartily
in support of the Society, agree
with its aims and endeavors, and
are, therefore, glad of the opportunity to help it along.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 12, 1913.
SENIOR PROM THURSDAY, JUNE 5

SAMPLE SALESCRECK

To Be One of Most Attractive Events of
Year—Fisher's Orchestra Tennis
Costumes to Be Worn.

Isaac Hamburger & Sons

The Senior Prom Committee has
decided that the date for the 1913
dance shall be Thursday, June 5.
It has also decided that this dance
shall be the best held in McCoy
Hall for some years, and it will
have to ''go some" to beat the cotillons of the season just past. The
Senior Prom Committee is divided
into smaller committees. Each of
these smaller ones is doing its best
.to outdo the others in thinking up
good things for the senior dance.
The supper, the punch, the music,
.the decorations, the souvenirs, all
.are going to be the best ever.
McCoy Hall always looks extremely gay. on the night .of, the
-senior prom. On June 5 • streamers of the class colors vill stretch
from the middle of the ceiling to
all corners. Class banners of various colors will hang over the
corridors. Palms will stretch across
the platform, and, behind these,
Fisher's Orchestra will, in ragtime
style, play "Down in New Orleans"
and "Here Comes My Daddy
Now." The girls will be the prettiest of Baltimore. And the fellows,
with their flannel trousers and blue
coats, will give to the hall a delightfully summer appearance. The
fellow who misses this senior prom
will miss• one of the most attractive
events of the year.
• Freshman Tennis Team.

The freshman tennis team is now
a reality. A large squad of Men
have been practicing ever since the
Homewood field opened this, season,
and though some have -dropped,
the squad still numbers . between
twelve ,and fifteen men. .Since an
elimination tournament • was impracticable, it has become an exceedingly difficult matter to pick
the men to play on the team.
. The schedule is by no means a
light owe and provides for five and
possibly six matches. On May 2
the team met. the City College contingent, losing, unfortunately, all
the matches in singles ; but winning, however, in the doubles. On
Friday, May 9, they met the Polytechnic team. On the 14th .the
;team will try conclusions with Marstons on the i6th, Gilman's Country School, and on the 23rd, the
sophomore class team. The schedule calls for a great deal of hard
work, but the team is expected to
come through with a majority of
wins.
The match with the sophomores
has been placed last on the schedule, naturally enough, and it will
be as keenly disputed and as hard
fought, as any of the freshmansophomore events.
The team: Hardy, Hayes, McDowell, Thomas, Rowland, Evitt,
and Web Peploe, manager.

Dr. Charles F. Painter Honored.

In the appointment of Dr. Charles
Nr. Painter, of the Class of 1891,
as dean of one of the largest medical schools in the country—the
medical school of Tuft's College, at
edford, Mass.—another honor has
come to a graduate of our University.

Dr. Painter has been for the last
seven years a professor of surgery
at the school of which he now becomes dean. He is a member of a
numebr of medical societies in this
country and the editor-in-chief of
the American Association of Orthopedic Surgery.

The following official announcement has been posted on the bulletin boards of the University and
Medical School:
Annual Johns Hopkins Tennis
Tournament, 1913.
"The 'Varsity Tennis Tournament
for 1913 will commence Wednesday, Max' 14, and will continue
thereafter daily until' completed.
Play will begin each afternoon at
4.30, though matches may be played
b.\ agreement at any hour. The
events will be singles, doubles and
consolation singles. All contestants
defeated in the first round actually
played will be eligible for the consolations. Prizes will be awarded
to the winner and runner-up in
singles; the winner in the consolations, and the winners of the
doubles. Any regularly registered
member of any department of the
University is eligible to enter the
tournament.
"All seven courts at Homewood
will be used, and Wright and Ditson championship balls will be furnished for each match.
"The entrance fee will be fifty
cents for the singles, and fifty cents
for each member of a team in
doubles, for those men who hold
five-dollar gymnasium lockers; for
all others the fee will be one dollar
for the singles and one dollar for
the doubles. Send entries to one
of the following:
"H. E. Corner, '14, Box 102; A.
L. Hammond,'14, Box 252; Julian
Marshall,'is; William Merrick,'15,
and Hiram Woodward, '16."
The Tournament has been set for
an earlier date than usual this year,
so as to leave plenty of time before
examinations. In addition, the late
hour for starting in the afternoon
will allow those to play who would
not wish to cut "lab."
The success of the Tournament
in previous years and the tennis
boom during this spring seems to
assure a large number of entries.
Although as many as forty-eight
entries were received last year, the
1913 committee had already a good
part of that number even on Saturday. One good indication is the
number of men from the lower
classes who will compete. The ,
winners of the singles tournaments
of the last three years were: 1910,
Perce; 1911, Post; 1912, DuBray.
"Johnny" Huck was runner-up in
1911, Julian Sears in 1912. The
three last mentioned men are still
at the University.
Next Saturday morning the 'Varsity tennis team will play Lehigh
University at Homewood. The
visiting team will be entertained in
Baltimore Thursday night. Lehigh conies here with a formidable
reputation in tennis. They have
already met such teams as Wesleyan, Lafayette, and Haverford.
Lehigh is captained by a Baltimorean, Ferdinand Turnbull,

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 12, 1913.
BOAT RIDE ON FRIDAY, JUNE 6
Seniors Plan Prom,Boat Ride, Gala Day,
and Classday for Senior Week,
June 5 to 10, Inclusive.

At a meeting of the senior class,
held last Friday, the final report of
the. Senior Week Committee was
unanimously adopted. The report
in condensed 'form, and the several
subcommittees are as follows:
J. E. Richardson, Jr., chairman
ex-officio of all the committees.
Thursday at 8.30 P. M., Senior
Prom; Donoho, chairman; Schmied,
Ray, Uhler, Brady.
Friday at 3 P. M., boat ride;
Sears, Sattler, Jacobs.
Saturday at 3 P. M., Homewood
Gala Day; at 8 P. M., supper at
Thompson's; Meekins, Breuninger.
Monday at 3 P. M., Class Day,
Rusk; Class Play, written by Wolman, Rusk and Hildebrandt; Class
Valedictory, by J. S. Dickinson;
address by Honorary Class President. At 8 P. M., Reception given
by Dean Griffin to seniors at the
Hopkins Club.
Tuesday at 3 P. M., Commencement; at 8 P. M., Faculty reception.
Invitations in charge of G. E. W.
Hardy, Jr.
Senior prom tickets can be secured from Donoho for $2.50. The
seniors who have paid their class

dues and the senior week assessment will be given the boat ride
free. The underclasses will be addressed by Chairman Richardson
during the coming week, when the
price of tickets will be announced
and other arrangements for the
boat ride will be made.

"By the teeth !" exclaimed Pat.

"No," admitted Casey, "but Oi
have."

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
Election to Phi Beta Kappa.

May 12, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LIMER :
DP:AR SIR—The advisability of an
intellectual aristocracy is seldom
questioned. Perhaps this is true because a criticism of so well established an institution as the Phi Beta
happa might seem to be prompted
by those whom we call "sore-heads"
and "sour grapes." There is,.however, wisdom in the objections which
might be advocated against the
method of recruiting this notable
fraternity. That no other method
.of election has been adjudged practicable seems to alter the case but
slightly.
The absurdity of over-classification attributed t9 Matthew Arnold,
who insisted on grading mathematically the victims of his literary
criticism, can be applied to these
Phi Beta Kappa elections. Psychologists, it is true, may feel that
there is a relation between the power of the intellect and the actual
weight of the brain. Nevertheless,
it is to be hoped that our wits will
refrain from proposing the chemical balance as a Phi Beta Kappa
qualification. It seems almcst as
ridiculous, furthermore, to consider
the tens which the "bluffers- and the
"bootlickers" pull as indices to the
highest order of mental development. True, this year's selection is
entirely irrelevant to this discussion—Mr. Dickinson, Mr. 1\ fartin,
Mr. Sears,.Mr. \\Tolman, Mr. Nodeserving
vak and Mr. Gruse
of the highest honors.
Even Professor Ames with all
his mathematical dexterity would
fail, should .he try the impossible.
"Brain ?—you can't give a number to
it !" In the graduate department
those who received their keys have
been tested by a far better standard.
The strength of intellect is not
tossed about in the shape .of nines
and tens, through meaningless additions and divisions. The inadequacy of.Phi Beta Kappa qualifications cannot, nevertheless, be
championed as an excuse for doing
poor work. Because Woodrow
Wilson happened to stand fortieth
in his class is no reason for one
flunking "Pyhsics and Psychology...
HOPKINSON T AN.

DEBATING COUNCIL

The Western High School of
Washington captured the third annual interscholastic meet which was
held in conjunction with the Carlisle meet and promoted by the
University Athletic Association.
Western High School had 28
points; Mercersburg, 26; Episcopal
High School, 21 ; Tome, Jo; Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, 9; Baltimore City College, 6; Gilman's
Country School, 5.
Some hundred and odd schoolboys took part in the contests, making it the greatest scholastic meet
held recently in these parts. The
inclement weather was detrimental
to good performances; nevertheless,
the work of several individuals was
creditable. Kinsolving-, of Episcopal, won first in the high hurdles,
second in the low, first in the high
jump and second in the broad
jump. Jones, of Western High
School, won three events, the wo
and 220 yard dashes, and the broad
jump.
Polytechnic won the mile relay
race from City College with ease.
The race was won in the first lap
after a considerable distance had
been gained by Jacobs, the B. P. I.
runner. Jacobs had previously won
the 220 low hurdles.
